page.title: 07BEDGEBURY FOREST
page.content: This forms one of the largest single blocks of woodland in S.E. England, straddling the county boundary of Kent and E. Sussex, totalling 970 hectares. Before 1924 when it was acquired by the Forestry Commission it was part of the Crown Estates, managed as mainly broadleaved woodland with a large part under chestnut coppice and worked on a 15-20 year rotation. The forest now consists of 78% conifers and 22% hardwoods producing an average volume of about 4200 cubic metres of timber per year. The produce is sold standing and markets include saw logs for building, pulpwood, mining timber and fencing material. The forest today has a wide appeal to the public. Recreational pursuits include riding, orienteering, wildlife and environmental studies. Adjacent to the forest block is the Pinetum.
